description: The RDS tech skills show will demonstrate how to get started with RDS on Windows Server 2012 R2.  In this show you’ll learn about setting up a “single” server RDS deployment, configuring it and securing it to work.  Also you’ll see the setting up a “clustered” server RDS deployment environment for High Availability to provide for failover and scalability.  Through the setup you’ll also gain knowledge of the different role services involved in an RDS deployment.
descriptionMD: The RDS tech skills show will demonstrate how to get started with RDS on Windows Server 2012 R2.  In this show you’ll learn about setting up a “single” server RDS deployment, configuring it and securing it to work.  Also you’ll see the setting up a “clustered” server RDS deployment environment for High Availability to provide for failover and scalability.  Through the setup you’ll also gain knowledge of the different role services involved in an RDS deployment.
name: Remote Desktop Services (RDS)
subtitle: Implementing Remote Desktop Services

episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.490
[SOUND] Welcome,
if you've ever wondered how to configure

2
00:00:04.490 --> 00:00:09.174
remote desktop services,
this is the perfect show for you.

3
00:00:09.174 --> 00:00:12.407
In this series, you'll learn how to
set up and configure a deployment,

4
00:00:12.407 --> 00:00:14.390
including high availability.

5
00:00:14.390 --> 00:00:18.570
And we have Mr. Ronnie Wong in studio to
help cover some topics that will be shown.

6
00:00:18.570 --> 00:00:19.829
>> Hey, that's right, Cherokee.

7
00:00:19.829 --> 00:00:23.913
The very fact is that when we start
setting up remote desktop services,

8
00:00:23.913 --> 00:00:27.875
it's not normally a topic that we
kind of jump into the IT world to do.

9
00:00:27.875 --> 00:00:31.300
It's something in which our
customer has normally requested.

10
00:00:31.300 --> 00:00:35.170
So those customers, usually there is two
different types, a very small environment

11
00:00:35.170 --> 00:00:40.110
and they wanna control the applications as
well as the desktops that are accessible.

12
00:00:40.110 --> 00:00:44.930
And then there are larger companies
that also want to do the same thing, but

13
00:00:44.930 --> 00:00:47.210
have the ability to continue to grow and

14
00:00:47.210 --> 00:00:50.200
to continue to face
the demands that are available.

15
00:00:50.200 --> 00:00:54.080
So first what we're going to take a look
at in the series that's coming up here,

16
00:00:54.080 --> 00:00:57.010
is how do we build a single
server deployment?

17
00:00:57.010 --> 00:01:00.960
Now, technically, it's a single server,
but we're gonna show you with two instead

18
00:01:00.960 --> 00:01:04.790
because Microsoft doesn't actually
support a single server deployment.

19
00:01:04.790 --> 00:01:08.573
Then from that point, once we get
everything configured and working, we're

20
00:01:08.573 --> 00:01:12.716
then going to show you how to configure
it for, well, a multi-server environment.

21
00:01:12.716 --> 00:01:16.509
And that means putting those different
roles on different machines, and

22
00:01:16.509 --> 00:01:18.650
allowing us to expand this out.

23
00:01:18.650 --> 00:01:22.210
The true goal and nature behind this
is what we call high availability,

24
00:01:22.210 --> 00:01:24.830
giving us both the ability to
load balance, in other words, for

25
00:01:24.830 --> 00:01:29.090
a good performance,
as well as to be able to have scalability,

26
00:01:29.090 --> 00:01:33.680
to add in servers as we need to,
to grow for higher demand as well.

27
00:01:33.680 --> 00:01:37.250
So we'll go through everything
in both of those processes,

28
00:01:37.250 --> 00:01:39.900
such as setting up the remote
connection broker.

29
00:01:39.900 --> 00:01:44.550
Also of course, the remote web access,
the remote web access server

30
00:01:44.550 --> 00:01:49.000
as well as the idea of using the remote
desktop gateway and, of course,

31
00:01:49.000 --> 00:01:51.450
the remote desktop session host servers.

32
00:01:51.450 --> 00:01:54.280
We'll configure all of that
to make sure that it works so

33
00:01:54.280 --> 00:01:56.620
that that way you can get started.

34
00:01:56.620 --> 00:01:58.750
And this series is
really just a beginning.

35
00:01:58.750 --> 00:02:02.460
As there are more and more complex
solutions that come along, well,

36
00:02:02.460 --> 00:02:04.600
at least you'll have the basics here.

37
00:02:04.600 --> 00:02:07.750
So if that's what you're looking for,
is how do I get started and

38
00:02:07.750 --> 00:02:12.480
set up, so that I can at least get this to
a point where I can start testing it out.

39
00:02:12.480 --> 00:02:16.440
This is what this series is designed
to do, and to show you as well.

40
00:02:16.440 --> 00:02:20.031
So if that's what you're looking for,
make sure you stay tuned for

41
00:02:20.031 --> 00:02:22.996
the first episodes that
are coming up right after this.

42
00:02:22.996 --> 00:02:26.329
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee introduce the concept of Remote Desktop Services, a Microsoft technology. The actual deployment you will see set up is called a single server configuration however we are actually dealing with 2 machines in this configuration. Ronnie walks through the initial setup to get started.
episodes.title: Build Single Server RDS
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:01.781
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.781 --> 00:00:08.286
[CROSSTALK]
[SOUND]

3
00:00:08.286 --> 00:00:11.971
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.971 --> 00:00:15.090
>> Welcome to your
Remote Desktop Services show.

5
00:00:15.090 --> 00:00:17.170
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.170 --> 00:00:21.540
If you're wondering how to start and where
to begin to build up this network service,

7
00:00:21.540 --> 00:00:23.000
well then,
you are definitely in the right place.

8
00:00:23.000 --> 00:00:27.500
Because today, we have Mr. Ronnie Wong in
studios to introduce us to this concept.

9
00:00:27.500 --> 00:00:28.950
Thank you for joining us today, Ronnie.

10
00:00:28.950 --> 00:00:29.710
>> Well, thank you for

11
00:00:29.710 --> 00:00:35.300
having me here as we begin to take
a look at remote desktop services.

12
00:00:35.300 --> 00:00:40.340
So when we start talking about this
particular concept, most of the time,

13
00:00:40.340 --> 00:00:42.290
there's a reason why we need this, right?

14
00:00:42.290 --> 00:00:45.440
We find out that there's some
particular implementation

15
00:00:45.440 --> 00:00:47.150
that we're told that we need to have.

16
00:00:47.150 --> 00:00:50.380
But a lot of times if you're brand new to
this, and you just turned on this show,

17
00:00:50.380 --> 00:00:53.610
and you go that seems interesting,
let's do that,

18
00:00:53.610 --> 00:00:56.110
you may not know why we're talking
about it or why we need it.

19
00:00:56.110 --> 00:00:57.638
So that's what we wanna begin with.

20
00:00:57.638 --> 00:01:00.240
And we wanna make sure that we understand
why in the world we're actually

21
00:01:00.240 --> 00:01:01.460
trying to use this.

22
00:01:01.460 --> 00:01:04.650
And then,
we're gonna begin with an implementation

23
00:01:04.650 --> 00:01:07.700
that will allow you to just get started,
right?

24
00:01:07.700 --> 00:01:10.950
And this doesn't necessarily mean it's
gonna be the best implementation.

25
00:01:10.950 --> 00:01:14.895
It is going to be something in which we
get started with, which we call a single

26
00:01:14.895 --> 00:01:18.434
server type of build, but
we'll talk about the reason behind that.

27
00:01:18.434 --> 00:01:20.923
And then we'll also talk about
how we get it set up, and

28
00:01:20.923 --> 00:01:24.220
that's what we'll hope to cover
in this particular episode.

29
00:01:24.220 --> 00:01:28.914
So, Cherokee, the idea of remote desktop
services, we're pretty familiar with it.

30
00:01:28.914 --> 00:01:32.500
I've actually got this running in
a couple different companies before.

31
00:01:32.500 --> 00:01:36.435
Cherokee, I think you've done the same, so
let's talk about the needs that we found

32
00:01:36.435 --> 00:01:40.130
out inside of the companies before
when we've done something like this.

33
00:01:40.130 --> 00:01:44.030
>> Okay, so Ronnie, I don't know if
you knew this, but many moons ago,

34
00:01:44.030 --> 00:01:47.700
I was an on-site repair technician, and

35
00:01:47.700 --> 00:01:50.440
I never really knew what kind
of job I was walking into.

36
00:01:50.440 --> 00:01:54.043
Sometimes I wouldn't get too much
notes about the particular client,

37
00:01:54.043 --> 00:01:56.937
I'd walk up and
not really know who was behind that door.

38
00:01:56.937 --> 00:02:01.665
Overall, though, everyone in my experience
was pretty cool, humans in general,

39
00:02:01.665 --> 00:02:04.830
I found, they were easygoing, right?

40
00:02:04.830 --> 00:02:07.170
But I approached a door one day, and

41
00:02:07.170 --> 00:02:13.010
it was a woman who had a small business
and her hard drive actually failed.

42
00:02:13.010 --> 00:02:16.450
So I would carry around all these parts
in my trunk, I know it's kind of crazy.

43
00:02:16.450 --> 00:02:21.104
And I had to fix her system, and we
brought the operating system back up, and

44
00:02:21.104 --> 00:02:24.108
she had a flash drive of
her QuickBooks backups.

45
00:02:24.108 --> 00:02:26.890
And we were able to go ahead and
install and bring them back up.

46
00:02:26.890 --> 00:02:30.060
But she hadn't created her backups,
but a few months ago.

47
00:02:30.060 --> 00:02:33.867
So she lost all the information
because of that hardware failure.

48
00:02:33.867 --> 00:02:38.078
Now, for a small business, that may be
acceptable, not necessarily acceptable,

49
00:02:38.078 --> 00:02:42.270
but she might have not been able to
afford a more expensive implementation.

50
00:02:42.270 --> 00:02:45.730
On the business side,
we really don't allow for

51
00:02:45.730 --> 00:02:48.390
those types of problems or we shouldn't.

52
00:02:48.390 --> 00:02:52.270
We should try to mitigate those by
implementing something like RDS.

53
00:02:52.270 --> 00:02:56.380
So in this show, we'll be looking at how
to go ahead and set it up and explain

54
00:02:56.380 --> 00:03:01.350
why it's useful and just how to configure
that and different things here, right?

55
00:03:01.350 --> 00:03:04.330
>> Yeah, that pretty much helps us
to summarize a couple of different

56
00:03:04.330 --> 00:03:05.350
things, right?

57
00:03:05.350 --> 00:03:09.250
One, there is a need and an implementation
of things like the loss of data.

58
00:03:09.250 --> 00:03:12.700
The very fact that people continually
in a business environment,

59
00:03:12.700 --> 00:03:15.620
whether you're talking about
just a regular work group, or

60
00:03:15.620 --> 00:03:17.810
you're talking about
an Active Directory network.

61
00:03:17.810 --> 00:03:21.370
People will still continue to rely on
their desktop machines as if they're

62
00:03:21.370 --> 00:03:26.240
dedicated machines that can withstand
any type of disaster that's out there.

63
00:03:26.240 --> 00:03:29.430
And the problem with those hard drives
is that they're relatively cheap and

64
00:03:29.430 --> 00:03:34.190
they shouldn't be relied on for anything
in which is gonna be very mission critical

65
00:03:34.190 --> 00:03:36.520
or anything that's a valuable data.

66
00:03:36.520 --> 00:03:39.514
Thats why of course inside of a business,
we constantly tell them,

67
00:03:39.514 --> 00:03:41.470
please store things in your shared folder.

68
00:03:41.470 --> 00:03:42.636
>> [LAUGH] Right.

69
00:03:42.636 --> 00:03:46.023
>> Cuz we can back those things up very
easily instead of what you're talking

70
00:03:46.023 --> 00:03:48.110
about where you're backing up everything.

71
00:03:48.110 --> 00:03:51.910
And then now you have to go and figure
out how do I get that data off of there,

72
00:03:51.910 --> 00:03:52.785
can I recover it?

73
00:03:52.785 --> 00:03:57.285
Well, that's some of the things in which
you begin to do, but if you're trying to

74
00:03:57.285 --> 00:04:01.560
repair that and do that machine by
machine, it becomes very costly.

75
00:04:01.560 --> 00:04:03.320
So there comes a point in
which you might try and

76
00:04:03.320 --> 00:04:07.780
look for another solution in which
is where I kind of came in at

77
00:04:07.780 --> 00:04:12.610
a remote desktop solution is that I
ended up getting for a company here.

78
00:04:12.610 --> 00:04:14.690
They said here's what
we need to implement,

79
00:04:14.690 --> 00:04:17.420
and here's what we want to try and do.

80
00:04:17.420 --> 00:04:20.310
So what happened is that they started

81
00:04:20.310 --> 00:04:23.850
to come to the end of life of
where their machines were.

82
00:04:23.850 --> 00:04:26.180
So they normally tried to
replace them every three years,

83
00:04:26.180 --> 00:04:29.780
but in this particular economy at
that point in time, they said,

84
00:04:29.780 --> 00:04:34.430
we can't afford to replace the 75 or
100 computers.

85
00:04:34.430 --> 00:04:38.880
What can we do if we were to try and
do it for this much amount of money?

86
00:04:38.880 --> 00:04:42.150
And we still need for everybody to
have a machine in front of them.

87
00:04:42.150 --> 00:04:46.560
We still need it to do things,
like they don't know anything's happened.

88
00:04:46.560 --> 00:04:51.156
But those older machines were no longer
able to run the software that they needed

89
00:04:51.156 --> 00:04:53.363
for their client management system.

90
00:04:53.363 --> 00:04:55.630
I was trying to remember what it's called,
the CMS.

91
00:04:55.630 --> 00:04:59.281
Some type of client management system that
they were having, so they needed more

92
00:04:59.281 --> 00:05:03.104
powerful computers, but they didn't have
brand new computers that could do that.

93
00:05:03.104 --> 00:05:06.738
They also of course needed to be able
to control what was being put on those

94
00:05:06.738 --> 00:05:10.313
computers, there were a lot of malware
infections that were going on in

95
00:05:10.313 --> 00:05:12.000
their systems, and you name it.

96
00:05:12.000 --> 00:05:13.800
They weren't able to do a lot of that.

97
00:05:13.800 --> 00:05:16.290
They had to continue
to fight against that.

98
00:05:16.290 --> 00:05:18.470
So one of the recommendations
by the company I work for

99
00:05:18.470 --> 00:05:21.760
said let's think about this idea
of remote desktop services.

100
00:05:21.760 --> 00:05:25.990
>> So, when you mention malware, so
let's say that individual's machine was

101
00:05:25.990 --> 00:05:29.770
infected, and from a business perspective,
like we spoke about before,

102
00:05:29.770 --> 00:05:32.450
instead of finding that root cause,
cleaning the machine.

103
00:05:32.450 --> 00:05:36.330
If that individual had stored their
information in the shared folder or

104
00:05:36.330 --> 00:05:40.078
some other alternative, then you could
just completely blow out that machine,

105
00:05:40.078 --> 00:05:44.680
re-image it, get it back up and running,
or just swap that machine out for

106
00:05:44.680 --> 00:05:48.110
that end user, and they would
still have access to their files.

107
00:05:48.110 --> 00:05:49.680
Quick, easy solution.

108
00:05:49.680 --> 00:05:53.720
>> Right, quick and easy, but
it's still costly in terms of time, right?

109
00:05:53.720 --> 00:05:57.160
Regardless of how fast your systems
are and bringing somebody down

110
00:05:57.160 --> 00:06:01.480
during a workday to re-image your system,
getting them set back up.

111
00:06:01.480 --> 00:06:04.361
It sounds like something that's easy,
and it's easier than not doing it.

112
00:06:04.361 --> 00:06:08.550
Of course, it's easier than trying to
figure it all out, but time is still

113
00:06:08.550 --> 00:06:13.570
the issue, okay, so what we presented
instead was a remote desktop solution.

114
00:06:13.570 --> 00:06:18.280
Where they could, instead, everybody could
have still the same machines that they

115
00:06:18.280 --> 00:06:22.950
were on, which were older computers, we
were extending the life of those machines.

116
00:06:22.950 --> 00:06:27.010
Instead, they would get a desktop
presented to them by the actual

117
00:06:27.010 --> 00:06:31.200
remote desktop services found inside
of Windows Server 2008 by that point.

118
00:06:31.200 --> 00:06:35.900
But we can also do it in Server 2012,
R2 is what we're gonna be doing here.

119
00:06:35.900 --> 00:06:38.650
So, all that can actually be extended and
helps us out.

120
00:06:38.650 --> 00:06:43.950
So in this particular situation, you might
find out that this is what has to happen,

121
00:06:43.950 --> 00:06:47.130
is that you might have this type
of solution where you go, look,

122
00:06:47.130 --> 00:06:50.120
here's what we need, and
this is probably the best solution.

123
00:06:50.120 --> 00:06:54.150
One, it gives them a desktop in which
we're gonna be able to control, okay,

124
00:06:54.150 --> 00:06:55.510
which is key.

125
00:06:55.510 --> 00:07:00.320
The very fact is, we can control whether
or not they can install software.

126
00:07:00.320 --> 00:07:04.100
And we might say, look, they're not
installing any software at all.

127
00:07:04.100 --> 00:07:07.090
If there's software installations
that we need to have,

128
00:07:07.090 --> 00:07:09.860
then it's controlled by me or by Cherokee.

129
00:07:09.860 --> 00:07:12.890
And I say, Cherokee, yes, this is
allowed or we say, no, it's not allowed,

130
00:07:12.890 --> 00:07:14.530
we're not gonna allow that to happen.

131
00:07:14.530 --> 00:07:19.890
We, of course, can also then redirect
their storage to a centralized location,

132
00:07:19.890 --> 00:07:22.770
and the user doesn't really
have to know about it.

133
00:07:22.770 --> 00:07:25.760
So, using even things like group
policy that we normally find in

134
00:07:25.760 --> 00:07:28.760
an Active Directory network,
we of course then can say look,

135
00:07:28.760 --> 00:07:31.570
here's where your My Documents
folder is gonna be.

136
00:07:31.570 --> 00:07:34.790
It looks just like that on your desktop,
the one that you had before.

137
00:07:34.790 --> 00:07:36.310
And you're gonna save
it in the same place.

138
00:07:36.310 --> 00:07:40.290
So everything actually ends up working
the way that you want it to, okay?

139
00:07:40.290 --> 00:07:42.334
So in that particular sense,

140
00:07:42.334 --> 00:07:47.977
we can essentially eliminate a lot of the
pitfalls of just having a regular desktop

141
00:07:47.977 --> 00:07:53.320
system by worrying about things like
power supply units and stuff like that.

142
00:07:53.320 --> 00:07:54.837
If those machines are still up and
running,

143
00:07:54.837 --> 00:07:56.580
we don't have to worry
about upgrading them.

144
00:07:56.580 --> 00:07:57.889
They simply log in.

145
00:07:57.889 --> 00:08:01.339
They're opening that remote desktop
connection, and they're ready to go, and

146
00:08:01.339 --> 00:08:03.400
we can do stuff like that as well.

147
00:08:03.400 --> 00:08:07.030
>> Now Ronnie, we say RDS for
Remote Desk, excuse me.

148
00:08:07.030 --> 00:08:07.920
>> Desktop Services, yep.

149
00:08:07.920 --> 00:08:10.120
>> Desktop services, I was like okay,
I forgot for a second.

150
00:08:10.120 --> 00:08:14.670
But if we kind of compare that to
another term you may have heard, VDI,

151
00:08:14.670 --> 00:08:19.620
Virtual Desktop Infrastructure, it's a
little confusing because they're similar,

152
00:08:19.620 --> 00:08:21.350
but not exactly the same, right.

153
00:08:21.350 --> 00:08:26.120
If you hear that term out in the field,
RDS is exclusive to Microsoft,

154
00:08:26.120 --> 00:08:30.200
so Microsoft's technology, so obviously
that's the environment you'll be using and

155
00:08:30.200 --> 00:08:31.560
we will be using here.

156
00:08:31.560 --> 00:08:35.100
If you hear the term VDI,
VDI can be used for other vendors and

157
00:08:35.100 --> 00:08:40.090
VDI is really going to be saying, look,
we are not centralizing, sharing out one

158
00:08:40.090 --> 00:08:44.940
particular operating system, we're giving
each end user a virtual machine that

159
00:08:44.940 --> 00:08:49.200
they're connecting to remotely, whereas
with remote desktop services, they're

160
00:08:49.200 --> 00:08:53.720
sharing that operating system, of course,
licensing, that's a whole another issue.

161
00:08:53.720 --> 00:08:57.910
Okay, you still have to pay for those
users connecting or machines connecting.

162
00:08:57.910 --> 00:09:03.990
But, You're just remoting in
those graphics, those commands.

163
00:09:03.990 --> 00:09:06.710
So you're all remoting into
that one operating system.

164
00:09:06.710 --> 00:09:09.720
There's not a virtual machine for
every single end user.

165
00:09:09.720 --> 00:09:15.605
So the underlying component, they're
a little bit different there with RDS and

166
00:09:15.605 --> 00:09:18.065
VDI but just kind of look
into that if you wanted to.

167
00:09:18.065 --> 00:09:20.679
>> Yeah and it is confusing
because language is different but

168
00:09:20.679 --> 00:09:21.808
it's vendor specific.

169
00:09:21.808 --> 00:09:25.979

now there it is, okay?

477
00:25:26.370 --> 00:25:27.290
So that pops up.

478
00:25:27.290 --> 00:25:29.280
It says connect to the remote PC.

479
00:25:29.280 --> 00:25:31.420
I can still do that.

480
00:25:31.420 --> 00:25:35.510
I can actually instead of putting in and
publishing it here, I can switch on over

481
00:25:35.510 --> 00:25:40.500
here and connect to that remote
PC by using just this web page.

482
00:25:40.500 --> 00:25:48.110
But since I went ahead and brought it up
the old standard way here, Let's do this.

483
00:25:48.110 --> 00:25:49.430
So this rd01itprotvdemo.

484
00:25:54.468 --> 00:25:55.849
Oops.

485
00:25:55.849 --> 00:25:59.044
Demo.com.

486
00:26:04.168 --> 00:26:10.100
My password is not super complicated but
I do apparently have issues typing it in.

487
00:26:10.100 --> 00:26:13.820
So now we should be able to get connected
in and have our full desktop session

488
00:26:13.820 --> 00:26:18.650
ready to go if everything does secure,
everything that we said it should.

489
00:26:18.650 --> 00:26:22.510
So, we can modify that collection
tower we need to to make it work

490
00:26:22.510 --> 00:26:24.700
the way that we need to, okay?

491
00:26:24.700 --> 00:26:26.150
Most of the time, right?

492
00:26:26.150 --> 00:26:29.600
If this is all you need,
it really does begin here, okay?

493
00:26:29.600 --> 00:26:32.670
But we're not completely down yet
and everything.

494
00:26:32.670 --> 00:26:33.730
And hopefully, there it goes.

495
00:26:33.730 --> 00:26:36.270
I was gonna say, this is taking
longer than I thought it would.

496
00:26:36.270 --> 00:26:41.350
But there it is we are now logged
in as a remote desktop user.

497
00:26:41.350 --> 00:26:43.732
There is a limitation though,
Cherokee that I have okay?

498
00:26:43.732 --> 00:26:48.110
Remember that little window I said we
should ignore, we shouldn't worry about.

499
00:26:48.110 --> 00:26:51.934
It still has the same limitations as it
were trying to connect we're in a desktop

500
00:26:51.934 --> 00:26:53.567
session into a server right now.

501
00:26:53.567 --> 00:26:55.690
Because there's no licensing,

502
00:26:55.690 --> 00:26:59.190
the maximum number of connections
I can have is two, okay?

503
00:26:59.190 --> 00:27:05.220
So if I have a group of employees of 50,
well, that's kind of crummy.

504
00:27:05.220 --> 00:27:06.780
>> Yeah.
>> At this particular point.

505
00:27:06.780 --> 00:27:09.530
So there's something else that
we definitely need to add in.

506
00:27:09.530 --> 00:27:12.110
And we still need to take care of.

507
00:27:12.110 --> 00:27:15.960
But at the same time, the other things
that we were pointing out earlier.

508
00:27:15.960 --> 00:27:17.240
Let me close out of this.

509
00:27:17.240 --> 00:27:18.586
I'm gonna just simply disconnect here.

510
00:27:20.723 --> 00:27:23.370
We still need to take care of this, okay?

511
00:27:23.370 --> 00:27:24.330
>> Our certificate issue?

512
00:27:24.330 --> 00:27:29.220
>> Yeah, the very fact is we're still
not secure in what we end up doing here.

513
00:27:29.220 --> 00:27:33.060
So this is something that we definitely
need to make sure that we take care of.

514
00:27:33.060 --> 00:27:37.250
And that means we've gotta go into
installing some certificates to

515
00:27:37.250 --> 00:27:38.445
make this work.

516
00:27:38.445 --> 00:27:42.560
That's gonna be better for us in the long
run especially we know that we gonna be

517
00:27:42.560 --> 00:27:46.870
using this and people are gonna be
connecting in remotely from the outside.

518
00:27:46.870 --> 00:27:50.720
It adds in how we secure the remote
desktop connections as well.

519
00:27:50.720 --> 00:27:53.810
So that's something else that we
definitely need to see in the single

520
00:27:53.810 --> 00:27:55.070
server environment.

521
00:27:55.070 --> 00:27:56.690
And once we're done with that,

522
00:27:56.690 --> 00:27:59.990
then at that point we can start talking
about some of these other issues.

523
00:27:59.990 --> 00:28:01.640
And we'll bring that all up together.

524
00:28:01.640 --> 00:28:04.790
But, Cherokee,
I think I've ran out of time again and

525
00:28:04.790 --> 00:28:07.490
that means that we need to go ahead and
end this show.

526
00:28:07.490 --> 00:28:08.780
>> All right, we'll go ahead and do that.

527
00:28:08.780 --> 00:28:09.960
But thank you so much, Ronnie for

528
00:28:09.960 --> 00:28:14.370
joining us today to show us how to
customize those individual sessions and

529
00:28:14.370 --> 00:28:18.120
I can't wait to look at how to really
secure those connections as well.

530
00:28:18.120 --> 00:28:19.890
And thank you, ladies and
gentlemen, for tuning in.

531
00:28:19.890 --> 00:28:20.730
Let's stay tuned.

532
00:28:20.730 --> 00:28:23.160
We have more remote desktop
services headed your way.

533
00:28:23.160 --> 00:28:26.750
I'm going to go ahead and sign off
as your show host, Cherokee Boose.

534
00:28:26.750 --> 00:28:27.660
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

535
00:28:27.660 --> 00:28:31.012
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

536
00:28:31.012 --> 00:28:36.999
[MUSIC]

537
00:28:36.999 --> 00:28:40.255
>> Thank you for watching, ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show you will see Cherokee and Ronnie discuss the need for connection security. They consider the pros and cons of using public vs private certification authorities. Watch Ronnie walk thru this process step by step.
episodes.title: Secure RDS Connections
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:06.727
[CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.727 --> 00:00:08.389
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.389 --> 00:00:12.240
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.240 --> 00:00:14.531
>> Welcome to your
Remote Desktop Services show.

5
00:00:14.531 --> 00:00:17.160
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.160 --> 00:00:18.640
Now, if you've being following along,

7
00:00:18.640 --> 00:00:22.210
you know that we've being heading down
this RDS journey, this path here.

8
00:00:22.210 --> 00:00:25.625
And we're actually at the point where
we need to think about security.

9
00:00:25.625 --> 00:00:28.111
With the ominous presence of well,
bad guys,

10
00:00:28.111 --> 00:00:31.120
this is definitely something
that we should consider.

11
00:00:31.120 --> 00:00:34.910
So in this show, we're gonna be
looking at Remote Desktop Services and

12
00:00:34.910 --> 00:00:37.170
how to secure those connections.

13
00:00:37.170 --> 00:00:39.600
With us today, we have Mr.
Ronnie Wong in studios.

14
00:00:39.600 --> 00:00:40.637
Thank you for joining us, Ronnie.

15
00:00:40.637 --> 00:00:41.931
>> Well, thank you for

16
00:00:41.931 --> 00:00:46.660
having me back as we take a look
now at doing that idea of security.

17
00:00:46.660 --> 00:00:48.671
There's probably many ways that
you can think about security.

18
00:00:48.671 --> 00:00:52.493
But because of the way that
Remote Desktop Services work,

19
00:00:52.493 --> 00:00:56.783
you've got to think a little
bit beyond just kind of saying,

20
00:00:56.783 --> 00:01:02.840
we'll just limit it to the domain users,
we'll just restrict it to these people.

21
00:01:02.840 --> 00:01:04.515
What we're also talking about, of course,

22
00:01:04.515 --> 00:01:06.639
is ensuring that we are connecting
to the right machine.

23
00:01:06.639 --> 00:01:07.855
Also, of course,

24
00:01:07.855 --> 00:01:13.110
being able to secure the communications
between those machines as well.

25
00:01:13.110 --> 00:01:16.270
And the best possible way for us to do
this, if we're not sure where people

26
00:01:16.270 --> 00:01:19.880
are connecting in from and
from what machines and whether or

27
00:01:19.880 --> 00:01:24.040
not they've connected before,
is to implement things like certificates.

28
00:01:24.040 --> 00:01:28.764
And that is really what are show at least
at this point is gonna focus in on,

29
00:01:28.764 --> 00:01:33.874
is the idea of making sure that we use
certificates not only on the machines, but

30
00:01:33.874 --> 00:01:39.089
also on helping us to secure the Remote
Desktop Services for those connections.

31
00:01:39.089 --> 00:01:41.790
And we'll show you of course
how to get that done.

32
00:01:41.790 --> 00:01:46.400
Now, up until this point, Cherokee,
we've gotten a few things configured.

33
00:01:46.400 --> 00:01:47.278
>> Yes we have.
>> So far, but

34
00:01:47.278 --> 00:01:50.352
we haven't configured everything that
we normally would need to configure.

35
00:01:50.352 --> 00:01:53.383
So we need to make sure that
we go through and do that, and

36
00:01:53.383 --> 00:01:56.180
we also need to make sure
that we use certificates.

37
00:01:56.180 --> 00:02:00.420
So let me go ahead and configure kind
of the other two things first, and

38
00:02:00.420 --> 00:02:02.710
then we'll come back and
what we'll do is certificates.

39
00:02:02.710 --> 00:02:04.080
Cuz, I held off on that.

40
00:02:04.080 --> 00:02:05.510
I didn't mean to, but I did.

41
00:02:05.510 --> 00:02:09.580
So, let's finish up that idea,
the configuration of what we need to do.

42
00:02:09.580 --> 00:02:11.260
So everything so far in that quickstart.

43
00:02:11.260 --> 00:02:12.430
We already talked about what we need.

44
00:02:12.430 --> 00:02:15.460
Let's take a look here at
Remote Desktop Services.

45
00:02:15.460 --> 00:02:17.700
So, if I click on
the Remote Desktop Services and

46
00:02:17.700 --> 00:02:21.160
I go to the overview,
I'll see the ones that are in gray,

47
00:02:21.160 --> 00:02:24.870
these are the ones that are marked
as being ready to operate.

48
00:02:24.870 --> 00:02:26.895
They are good to go, okay?

49
00:02:26.895 --> 00:02:27.525
To me, again,

50
00:02:27.525 --> 00:02:32.845
remember that I mentioned this,
this seems so backward intuitive to me.

51
00:02:32.845 --> 00:02:35.055
Gray normally means it's not functional,
at least for

52
00:02:35.055 --> 00:02:37.205
me when I start seeing applications here.

53
00:02:37.205 --> 00:02:38.945
Like, I can't access it,
I can't do anything.

54
00:02:38.945 --> 00:02:40.525
But that's not the way it is.

55
00:02:40.525 --> 00:02:43.255
It's the green plus signs that tell
you that something else needs to

56
00:02:43.255 --> 00:02:44.440
be configured.

57
00:02:44.440 --> 00:02:49.740
If I want more than one or two, actually,
two connections to happen, okay,

58
00:02:49.740 --> 00:02:55.110
to this server at any one time, I'm going
to need to add in a licensing server.

59
00:02:55.110 --> 00:02:57.655
So I'm going to go ahead and
click on this green plus sign.

60
00:02:57.655 --> 00:03:00.139
And when I do so, it's going to say, hey,

61
00:03:00.139 --> 00:03:03.710
where do I want the licensing
server to be installed?

62
00:03:03.710 --> 00:03:04.950
And this is important.

63
00:03:04.950 --> 00:03:08.400
Up until this point,
we've installed everything on RD01.

64
00:03:08.400 --> 00:03:09.910
Can I continue to do that if I want to?

65
00:03:09.910 --> 00:03:11.740
Absolutely, you can.

66
00:03:11.740 --> 00:03:15.600
But a licensing server is probably one of
those roles that you really want to be

67
00:03:15.600 --> 00:03:16.830
off by itself.

68
00:03:16.830 --> 00:03:20.010
Just in case that Remote Desktop
server goes down,

69
00:03:20.010 --> 00:03:22.480
you want the licensing server to be up.

70
00:03:22.480 --> 00:03:25.420
Just, when you bring it up,
people can connect in right away.

71
00:03:25.420 --> 00:03:29.970
So this time instead,
I'm going to add this on to DC01 and

72
00:03:29.970 --> 00:03:33.190
click Next here and
allow it to install the role.

73
00:03:33.190 --> 00:03:34.770
Now, when it does so,

74
00:03:34.770 --> 00:03:37.450
it's gonna install a couple of
other things here at the same time.

75
00:03:37.450 --> 00:03:41.250
And we need this to work,
is what we need, right?

76
00:03:41.250 --> 00:03:42.960
The licensing server is important.

77
00:03:42.960 --> 00:03:46.383
As people connect in,
they are gonna get access to a license.

78
00:03:46.383 --> 00:03:49.950
And now,
we actually need to have control of that.

79
00:03:49.950 --> 00:03:51.530
This is something you'll
have to go to Microsoft and

80
00:03:51.530 --> 00:03:56.190
get that Remote Desktop licensing, and
the number of licenses that you get and

81
00:03:56.190 --> 00:03:58.090
everything to make sure that it happens.

82
00:03:58.090 --> 00:03:59.539
But we're not gonna worry about that so
much.

83
00:03:59.539 --> 00:04:01.980
We just need to install the role here.

84
00:04:01.980 --> 00:04:05.910
We'll talk about configuring those
licenses a little bit later.

85
00:04:05.910 --> 00:04:09.895
But now notice, there it is,
licensing server is now installed.

86
00:04:09.895 --> 00:04:11.850
We're fine and we are ready to go.

87
00:04:12.900 --> 00:04:17.160
The other thing that we need to do is if I
think that people are gonna be connecting

88
00:04:17.160 --> 00:04:19.019
in from the outside of my network.

89
00:04:19.019 --> 00:04:21.800
If they're gonna be connecting in
from the outside of my network,

90
00:04:21.800 --> 00:04:23.960
I need this Remote Desktop gateway.

91
00:04:23.960 --> 00:04:26.910
So this is where you talk
to whoever the owner is and

92
00:04:26.910 --> 00:04:30.920
say, is there a chance that we
are gonna have remote users?

93
00:04:30.920 --> 00:04:33.148
People that are gonna be
logging in [CROSSTALK]

94
00:04:33.148 --> 00:04:34.036
>> Telecommuting.

95
00:04:34.036 --> 00:04:37.505
>> Yeah, telecommuting, logging in
over the weekend, outside, Salesforce,

96
00:04:37.505 --> 00:04:38.509
whatever it might be.

97
00:04:38.509 --> 00:04:41.050
If you are, you set up the RD gateway.

98
00:04:41.050 --> 00:04:43.704
I'm simply gonna put this back on RD01.

99
00:04:45.180 --> 00:04:46.520
And click Next.

100
00:04:46.520 --> 00:04:49.403
And you'll see that it just kind of
does its magic in the background,

101
00:04:49.403 --> 00:04:51.003
installing the role that it needs to.

102
00:04:51.003 --> 00:04:54.440
And now, notice it says, here it is.

103
00:04:54.440 --> 00:04:57.245
This is where we wanted to get to, because
this fills in with the certificate.

104
00:04:57.245 --> 00:04:57.800
>> Mm-hm.

105
00:04:57.800 --> 00:05:02.743
>> Says, hey, SSL certificates are used
to encrypt communications between

106
00:05:02.743 --> 00:05:06.442
Remote Desktop Services clients and
gateway servers.

107
00:05:06.442 --> 00:05:08.632
That's how people connect in.

108
00:05:08.632 --> 00:05:13.110
The self-signed certificate must match
the fully qualified domain name.

109
00:05:13.110 --> 00:05:15.280
So it's telling you this
is what you should do.

110
00:05:15.280 --> 00:05:17.230
So it's giving you this option right now.

111
00:05:17.230 --> 00:05:20.960
And it says, look, if you're going to
do a remote gateway, at least have

112
00:05:20.960 --> 00:05:27.330
a certificate on it so I know that that
certificate name is gonna be this.

113
00:05:29.280 --> 00:05:32.790
>> Now, Ronnie, what are we talking about
here, internal, external, does it matter?

114
00:05:32.790 --> 00:05:36.270
>> Well, for this one, this is gonna be
what the clients would get if they connect

115
00:05:36.270 --> 00:05:37.770
in from the external side.

116
00:05:37.770 --> 00:05:40.087
So right now it doesn't get
a self-signed certificate,

117
00:05:40.087 --> 00:05:42.415
that's still gonna leave that
red bar in the address bar.

118
00:05:42.415 --> 00:05:44.017
But it will at least give
them that certificate.

119
00:05:44.017 --> 00:05:46.810
And the strange thing is,
we already saw it, right?

120
00:05:46.810 --> 00:05:50.095
So even though we didn't have this
set up as far as remote gateway,

121
00:05:50.095 --> 00:05:53.685
if we were connecting in from
the Internet, this is what we're saying.

122
00:05:53.685 --> 00:05:55.150
Use that same certificate.

123
00:05:55.150 --> 00:05:56.250
But we're already using it,

124
00:05:56.250 --> 00:06:00.950
we already showed you on the thin PC
where we were actually able to use that.

125
00:06:00.950 --> 00:06:03.470
So now we're putting it on
that gateway server as well.

126
00:06:03.470 --> 00:06:05.460
Now, we're gonna change that in a moment.

127
00:06:05.460 --> 00:06:09.120
Or at least, during the show
we're going to change that, okay.

128
00:06:09.120 --> 00:06:10.689
But self-signed certificates,
they can work.

129
00:06:10.689 --> 00:06:13.508
Like I said, inside of your network,
more than likely,

130
00:06:13.508 --> 00:06:15.740
a self-signed certificate would work.

131
00:06:15.740 --> 00:06:16.900
I don't recommend it.

132
00:06:16.900 --> 00:06:19.021
I don't think anybody at
Microsoft recommends that.

133
00:06:19.021 --> 00:06:22.630
But at the same time, it's not like I
haven't done it before, where I say, yeah,

134
00:06:22.630 --> 00:06:23.728
just kinda ignore that.

135
00:06:23.728 --> 00:06:26.640
But it is a certificate there.

136
00:06:26.640 --> 00:06:30.020
But it's not something that
would be best practice, right?

137
00:06:30.020 --> 00:06:33.250
So here,
what we really want to do of course

138
00:06:33.250 --> 00:06:36.930
is get to that point where we're
not using self-signed certificates.

139
00:06:36.930 --> 00:06:38.380
>> Okay.
>> Especially if they're connecting in

140
00:06:38.380 --> 00:06:38.940
from the outside.

141
00:06:38.940 --> 00:06:41.700
That would be terrible for
us to be able to do.

142
00:06:41.700 --> 00:06:45.614
So while this is finishing installing
here, that's what we wanna do, is we wanna

143
00:06:45.614 --> 00:06:49.664
talk about this idea of using a different
certificate than what we're having here.

144
00:06:49.664 --> 00:06:53.180
And then also do that for
some of the other things that we need.

145
00:06:53.180 --> 00:06:55.470
And we'll show you where
to configure that as well.

146
00:06:55.470 --> 00:06:58.080
So, Cherokee,
when it comes down to certificates,

147
00:06:58.080 --> 00:07:01.200
there's really three different
types of certificates we can use.

148
00:07:01.200 --> 00:07:03.160
And the first one is
what we just looked at.

149
00:07:03.160 --> 00:07:05.610
A self-signed certificate unto itself.

150
00:07:05.610 --> 00:07:06.300
Okay?

151
00:07:06.300 --> 00:07:09.808
Now, is a self-signed certificate
really any worse than,

152
00:07:09.808 --> 00:07:12.560
like, a third-party certificate?

153
00:07:12.560 --> 00:07:15.440
No, they kind of give you the same thing.

154
00:07:15.440 --> 00:07:18.520
But the hard part about it is
that no one can validate that.

155
00:07:18.520 --> 00:07:21.160
So anybody can name their
certificate whatever they want to.

156
00:07:21.160 --> 00:07:22.378
>> Sure.
>> And hand that to you.

157
00:07:22.378 --> 00:07:25.350
So that's probably the option
we want the least.

158
00:07:25.350 --> 00:07:27.309
But if I wanted to, though, Cherokee,

159
00:07:27.309 --> 00:07:30.350
I could either get that
third-party certificate.

160
00:07:30.350 --> 00:07:33.030
The one that you can go out on
the Internet and find one and get that.

161
00:07:33.030 --> 00:07:38.293
Or I can use an internal CA, an internal
certificate authority and do that too.

162
00:07:38.293 --> 00:07:41.868
So let's talk about the pros and
cons of that a little bit, Cherokee, here.

163
00:07:41.868 --> 00:07:46.869
So let's talk about the pros here,
then, of using an internal CA.

164
00:07:46.869 --> 00:07:50.660
What do you think some of the pros are for
using an internal CA?

165
00:07:50.660 --> 00:07:53.590
>> Okay, so
I worked at a company where the owner,

166
00:07:53.590 --> 00:07:55.872
it was a high security environment.

167
00:07:55.872 --> 00:07:58.700
So they didn't want to give
that trust to a third entity.

168
00:07:58.700 --> 00:08:00.424
They said, no,
we're doing it all in-house.

169

00:30:31.671 --> 00:30:33.689
I am going to go ahead and
sign off as your show host.

567
00:30:33.689 --> 00:30:34.640
I'm Cherokee Boose.

568
00:30:34.640 --> 00:30:35.535
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

569
00:30:35.535 --> 00:30:38.333
See you next time here at ITProTV.

570
00:30:38.333 --> 00:30:45.374
[MUSIC]

571
00:30:45.374 --> 00:30:48.370
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee continue to configure additional RDS roles. Specifically, they discuss the role of the remote desktop gateway.  Watch Ronnie demonstrate how to configure the RD Gateway.
episodes.title: Configure Additional RDS Roles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.021 --> 00:00:07.756
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host Don-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:07.756 --> 00:00:11.560
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.560 --> 00:00:16.100
>> Welcome to your Remote Desktop Services
show, I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

4
00:00:16.100 --> 00:00:19.800
In the previous episode we
configured a secure connection, but

5
00:00:19.800 --> 00:00:22.276
we still have some configuring left to do.

6
00:00:22.276 --> 00:00:23.511
With us today, we have Mr.

7
00:00:23.511 --> 00:00:26.421
Ronnie Wong in studios, thank you for
joining us today Ronnie.

8
00:00:26.421 --> 00:00:29.404
>> Well, thank you for having me back
on the Remote Desktop Services show.

9
00:00:29.404 --> 00:00:33.122
And we do have a little bit more
that we need to zoom in on and

10
00:00:33.122 --> 00:00:34.757
get configured as well.

11
00:00:34.757 --> 00:00:38.278
Remember that in our set up so far,
Cherokee, as we did these kinda,

12
00:00:38.278 --> 00:00:42.713
single server deployment idea, that we did
show you that when you select that option,

13
00:00:42.713 --> 00:00:45.475
it automatically sets up
those three roles, right.

14
00:00:45.475 --> 00:00:49.279
The gateway, the web access and
the session host,

those are configured in the background.

16

You and I really don't have to touch them,

17
00:00:54.500 --> 00:00:58.770
except to change maybe the publishing app
and of course the add-in certificates.

18
00:00:58.770 --> 00:01:03.270
And we've seen all that before, and
that everything is kind of up and going.

19
00:01:03.270 --> 00:01:08.420
But there are a couple of other roles
in which I just simply added in, just

20
00:01:08.420 --> 00:01:12.080
to show you that we could, to make sure
that they're a part of the deployment.

21
00:01:12.080 --> 00:01:14.340
But we really didn't do anything
with them, I just kind of said,

22
00:01:14.340 --> 00:01:16.360
we're gonna hit that another show,
we're gonna hit that another show.

23
00:01:16.360 --> 00:01:20.550
Well today is that time that we
are gonna hit that in that other show.

24
00:01:20.550 --> 00:01:23.550
And so this is where we are, and
we wanna take a look specifically,

25
00:01:23.550 --> 00:01:28.770
then, at some of the options and
configurations we need to consider

26
00:01:28.770 --> 00:01:32.950
if we're gonna really implement
Remote Desktop, right.

27
00:01:32.950 --> 00:01:36.748
Not only, of course, for
internal users, but for external users.

28
00:01:36.748 --> 00:01:38.804
And that's what we're gonna focus in on,

29
00:01:38.804 --> 00:01:42.985
of course, configuring the Remote Desktop
Gateway, and why that one's important.

30
00:01:42.985 --> 00:01:44.525
The other thing, of course,

31
00:01:44.525 --> 00:01:48.570
is the Remote Desktop licensing role
that we also need to configure.

32
00:01:48.570 --> 00:01:52.300
Currently even though everything is
running, and everything is good,

33
00:01:52.300 --> 00:01:56.120
we saw where the certificate
issued out perfectly fine.

34
00:01:56.120 --> 00:01:58.099
And we're able to make
the connection that we need to.

35
00:01:58.099 --> 00:02:02.950
The issue that we have is still simple,
without licensing I have a limitation, and

36
00:02:02.950 --> 00:02:06.293
that limitation to that one
server has two connections.

37
00:02:06.293 --> 00:02:11.328
And as great as that is, two whole
connections is probably not sufficient for

38
00:02:11.328 --> 00:02:14.380
any particular business's real need.

39
00:02:14.380 --> 00:02:18.240
For a user at home probably okay, but
that's a lot of infrastructure set up for

40
00:02:18.240 --> 00:02:21.720
just a user at home to have
two additional connections.

41
00:02:21.720 --> 00:02:23.890
It really would be,
if you did all that for

42
00:02:23.890 --> 00:02:27.940
two connections, well you are a gung-ho
enthusiast on Windows Server 2012, and

43
00:02:27.940 --> 00:02:31.300
you're beyond an enthusiast at that point.

44
00:02:31.300 --> 00:02:33.750
But normally, most of us are doing this so

45
00:02:33.750 --> 00:02:39.220
that we actually can have the ability
to provide this type of connection or

46
00:02:39.220 --> 00:02:44.970
access to the applications in our network
for multiple users at the same time.

47
00:02:44.970 --> 00:02:47.310
So we need to configure
the licensing side too,

48
00:02:47.310 --> 00:02:51.080
and that's what we're also gonna
take a look at in this episode.

49
00:02:51.080 --> 00:02:54.320
And that may take us a few minutes as
we've gotta get a couple of connections

50
00:02:54.320 --> 00:02:58.160
down and do a couple of different
things to make that one work.

51
00:02:58.160 --> 00:03:03.080
But let's start off by talking
about this IDM of setting up

52
00:03:03.080 --> 00:03:06.040
the Remote Desktop Gateway
is what we want to do.

53
00:03:06.040 --> 00:03:09.160
>> All right, Ronnie ,why is
the Remote Desktop Gateway important?

54
00:03:09.160 --> 00:03:13.290
And what is the function and its
purpose relating to this configuration?

55
00:03:13.290 --> 00:03:14.990
>> Well, when it comes down to it,

56
00:03:14.990 --> 00:03:20.040
because all the tests that I've been
doing right now, we pretty much only

57
00:03:20.040 --> 00:03:25.900
been entering in the fully qualified
domain name of that server.

58
00:03:25.900 --> 00:03:29.420
Where the web server resides,
where the remote access server resides.

59
00:03:29.420 --> 00:03:33.360
And that's because I know it right then
and there, and everything is good.

60
00:03:33.360 --> 00:03:38.180
But if we were to try and connect to
it from the internet at this point.

61
00:03:38.180 --> 00:03:42.510
Well, it has to maybe go through
other things that are out there.

62
00:03:42.510 --> 00:03:46.190
And the problem that we have is that we
don't really wanna put that Remote Desktop

63
00:03:46.190 --> 00:03:48.270
machine, that we've got
everything set up on,

64
00:03:48.270 --> 00:03:50.410
right at there at the edge
of our network yard.

65
00:03:50.410 --> 00:03:51.690
But there may be a point when we do,

66
00:03:51.690 --> 00:03:55.010
when we actually separate
that roll out by itself.

67
00:03:55.010 --> 00:03:59.035
And we say if you are going to be
using Remote Desktop Services,

68
00:03:59.035 --> 00:04:01.630
you're gonna connect through that machine.

69
00:04:01.630 --> 00:04:04.830
And that's what that
Remote Desktop Gateway does for us.

70
00:04:04.830 --> 00:04:05.560
It provides for

71
00:04:05.560 --> 00:04:10.220
us an entry point to be able to get access
to those network resources that we want

72
00:04:10.220 --> 00:04:14.750
people to get access to,
even from outside of our network.

73
00:04:14.750 --> 00:04:17.450
Now you might be wondering
is that really important?

74
00:04:17.450 --> 00:04:21.000
Well, in today's world,
it's as important as anything else.

75
00:04:21.000 --> 00:04:24.580
We don't want the limitation
anymore of having what we call

76
00:04:24.580 --> 00:04:26.100
a bounded type of network.

77
00:04:26.100 --> 00:04:30.290
Where we can't access our resources when
we do, or we need to set up additional

78
00:04:30.290 --> 00:04:33.590
things so that we can do that,
even when I'm not out there, or

79
00:04:33.590 --> 00:04:36.602
when I'm not directly connected
inside of my network.

80
00:04:36.602 --> 00:04:40.220
So the Remote Desktop Gateway is,
first and foremost, right,

81
00:04:40.220 --> 00:04:44.575
the connection point that we need,
it's our presence out on the Internet for

82
00:04:44.575 --> 00:04:46.728
the Remote Desktop Services, okay.

83
00:04:46.728 --> 00:04:51.349
Secondly though, we also need
it to be a secured connection.

84
00:04:51.349 --> 00:04:53.915
And the problem that we have, once again,

85
00:04:53.915 --> 00:04:58.140
is now there's a couple of options
that are also in our way too, okay.

86
00:04:58.140 --> 00:05:03.813
One of those, of course, is security, the
idea of security here is very important

87
00:05:03.813 --> 00:05:09.710
to everybody on the planet as far as
getting the resources that we need to.

88
00:05:09.710 --> 00:05:15.410
If this Remote Desktop Server and
services is behind a firewall,

89
00:05:15.410 --> 00:05:19.500
well remember what that means, that every
time somebody connects in they have to be

90
00:05:19.500 --> 00:05:23.620
able to get through the firewall using,
well, a Remote Desktop connection.

91
00:05:23.620 --> 00:05:26.390
And when they do something like that,

92
00:05:26.390 --> 00:05:30.120
that's usually not a port that's
standardly turned on by every firewall.

93
00:05:30.120 --> 00:05:33.755
They're saying, if you want that to
happen, you need to make an exception for,

94
00:05:33.755 --> 00:05:35.980
well, RDP to connect in.

95
00:05:35.980 --> 00:05:40.560
And as much as you go well, okay, that's
only one app, but that's where people

96
00:05:40.560 --> 00:05:44.540
start having those security policies
that say, look we don't want to do this,

97
00:05:44.540 --> 00:05:48.280
we want to make sure that here's
the security that we allowed to com in.

98
00:05:48.280 --> 00:05:51.970
But we really don't wan to turn
on RDP if we don't need to.

99
00:05:51.970 --> 00:05:55.880
So, how do we get around something like
that if that's gonna be the truth and

100
00:05:55.880 --> 00:05:57.240
the nature of things?

101
00:05:57.240 --> 00:06:00.650
And that's where we added in
certificates to help us out too.

102
00:06:00.650 --> 00:06:03.080
The advantage of using
the Remote Desktop Gateway and

103
00:06:03.080 --> 00:06:07.590
providing that single point of entry is
that it really prevents us from even,

104
00:06:07.590 --> 00:06:12.670
not only having to go across 3389,
but we can go across SSL using 4443.

105
00:06:12.670 --> 00:06:15.580
But secondly,
we don't even have to provide

106
00:06:15.580 --> 00:06:19.540
another way to get around all that
by using VPNs anymore either.

107
00:06:19.540 --> 00:06:24.200
So if you have this set up,
even a VPN connection is not necessary for

108
00:06:24.200 --> 00:06:28.660
people to get a secure connection in to
the services that you want them to have.

109
00:06:28.660 --> 00:06:32.320
So that's why setting that one up
is actually a very important aspect

110
00:06:32.320 --> 00:06:33.560
of everything that we want.

111
00:06:33.560 --> 00:06:36.880
So there's pretty much that,
but those are kind of benefits,

112
00:06:36.880 --> 00:06:39.360
those are the reasons
why we wanna set it up.

113
00:06:39.360 --> 00:06:42.790
And that's the key, all right, so let's
take a look at what we've done so far and

114
00:06:42.790 --> 00:06:45.090

This is tricky,

So let's take a look at my screen.

How in the world are you gonna manage

So I click on Servers,

00:07:30.810 --> 00:07:34.490
But I always feel better about adding

129
00:07:34.490 --> 00:07:38.590
So that's just a personal thing, don't

130

And somebody's gonna definitely say, well,

Ronnie's silly in wanting

Now if I click back on it,

I simply took that green plus sign,

But that's all that we did here,

So at this point,

You don't because the reason why is that

So we know it can work in stuff like

So Cherokee, if you were to look

And I'm-

>> Yeah, I'm clicking on it and

my next thought is,

Well, look at that,
it says I can add one and

I can remove one, but-

So that doesn't give me

So where in the world do

00:09:20.640 --> 00:09:23.490
Now if those of you that don't that's
easy, Ronnie, I've been doing this for

00:09:23.490 --> 00:09:25.160

Remember not everybody that's watching

So that is our first hunt,

Well, this is where it

And now you have to remember which

So if I right click on RD01,
now you'll notice that

Now there's a couple of

So for instance,
if I right-click on this one,

I'm on DC1, at least that's where

00:10:12.160 --> 00:10:18.481
If I select RD Gateway Manager [SOUND]
I failed again Cherokee look at that.

Server Manager cannot open the tool.

00:10:22.120 --> 00:10:25.701
Yeah, there it is,
I'm kind of toast, I am done.

And now it says, Ronnie,
if you wanna do this,

you gotta add in a bunch of

00:10:31.710 --> 00:10:32.980
Boy, that sounds neat.

>> Or can we just switch

00:10:34.513 --> 00:10:35.801
[INAUDIBLE] [LAUGH]

[LAUGH] So I'm just trying to show

00:10:40.450 --> 00:10:43.197

00:10:43.197 --> 00:10:44.374
>> Right.
>> You go man, that was easy,

00:10:44.374 --> 00:10:45.060
that was great.

00:10:45.060 --> 00:10:49.070
And now you go all right, let me configure

And then you find it and
you're like [SOUND] I have to do all this?

No, as long as you have access to
the other machine you simply switch over,

00:10:57.548 --> 00:11:00.645

to do to this machine.

00:11:03.258 --> 00:11:08.270
And now that we're actually on RD01,
I can click back on Servers-

201

>> If I right-click,

the RD Gateway Manager and

this time when I select it
>> It gives me a whole another view

instead.

And that is the view that we want

it tells us exactly what its purpose is.

207
00:11:29.940 --> 00:11:35.210
The RD Gateway enables authorized
remote users to connect to resources on

208
00:11:35.210 --> 00:11:39.777
an internal corporate or private network
from any Internet-connected device.

209
00:11:39.777 --> 00:11:44.820
So currently,
remember that we only really have

that's just connected into the switch, so

So, even though I set it up and it's

it's not connecting,

But, the good thing is, the server

00:18:35.020 --> 00:18:37.850
So if you're using a proxy server,
you can use a bridging.

00:18:37.850 --> 00:18:41.200

00:18:41.200 --> 00:18:43.240

00:18:43.240 --> 00:18:46.100
So from the outside, they go to
the proxy server, and then now that

00:18:46.100 --> 00:18:48.810

00:18:48.810 --> 00:18:50.580
That's what SSL bridging is about.

00:18:50.580 --> 00:18:53.860
>> That's just because certain protocols,
like telling protocols,

00:18:53.860 --> 00:18:57.870
and six to four, four to six,

00:18:57.870 --> 00:18:59.685

00:18:59.685 --> 00:19:00.960

00:19:05.500 --> 00:19:08.580
So we don't really ever directly

00:19:08.580 --> 00:19:10.910
So if you're coming in from

specify a licensing server or

486
00:26:53.510 --> 00:26:55.290
to remove one if I need to.

487
00:26:55.290 --> 00:26:58.910
So I'm gonna select the per user at
this point and just click Apply.

488
00:27:01.060 --> 00:27:03.240
And once that gets applied,
we'll just check it out and

489
00:27:03.240 --> 00:27:05.010
see if we need to add a certificate.

490
00:27:05.010 --> 00:27:09.220
And if we do, we do, and if we don't, well
we don't worry about it too much here.

491
00:27:09.220 --> 00:27:11.660
But here, let's see, did that?

492
00:27:11.660 --> 00:27:13.375
I'm trying to think if, I think it's done.

493
00:27:13.375 --> 00:27:15.660
Okay, yeah, it allowed me to get there.

494
00:27:15.660 --> 00:27:19.910
But notice it's not requesting
another certificate for us.

495
00:27:19.910 --> 00:27:22.650
Everything is still trusted and
ready to go.

496
00:27:22.650 --> 00:27:26.210
So that is how we now take that licencing,

497
00:27:26.210 --> 00:27:30.380
we add in the licences,
excuse me, that we need to.

498
00:27:30.380 --> 00:27:34.870
We now enable which one we wanna do
whether it's per device or per user.

499
00:27:34.870 --> 00:27:40.660
And then once that's done, we just go back
and verify that everything is now working.

500
00:27:40.660 --> 00:27:42.000
Now, how do we verify that?

501
00:27:42.000 --> 00:27:44.750
Now, we go back to servers and

502
00:27:44.750 --> 00:27:48.684
then over on the RD01 where
everybody is connecting in,

503
00:27:48.684 --> 00:27:53.640
if I right click on it,
there is this option down here.

504
00:27:53.640 --> 00:27:57.544
Now, it didn't appear up here in
DC01 where the licensing server is,

505
00:27:57.544 --> 00:27:59.530
this here is the licensing manager.

506
00:28:00.600 --> 00:28:06.460
If I go to RD01, and
I go to Licensing Diagnoser,

507
00:28:06.460 --> 00:28:12.205
you can now see, did not identify
any licensing problems, hey.

508
00:28:12.205 --> 00:28:12.830
>> Woo-hoo.

509
00:28:12.830 --> 00:28:13.870
>> That's a good thing.

510
00:28:13.870 --> 00:28:14.370
>> Yeah.
>> There you go.

511
00:28:14.370 --> 00:28:15.856
So it didn't identify any.

512
00:28:15.856 --> 00:28:19.435
And now sees the 50 licenses available for

513
00:28:19.435 --> 00:28:21.079
the clients here and

514
00:28:21.079 --> 00:28:26.260
notice it tells me what mode I
am choosing to be able to do so.

515
00:28:26.260 --> 00:28:28.770
So, at this point,
you are now ready to go.

516
00:28:28.770 --> 00:28:31.560
The only other option
that I can think of that

517
00:28:31.560 --> 00:28:36.260
I was actually just thinking of this right
away here and let me check one more thing.

518
00:28:36.260 --> 00:28:37.030
Can we change it?

519
00:28:37.030 --> 00:28:38.080
That's what I don't know.

520
00:28:38.080 --> 00:28:39.800
Let's go to Edit Task.

521
00:28:39.800 --> 00:28:43.720
That's what I wanted to see cuz I've
never changed it once I've set it up.

522
00:28:43.720 --> 00:28:45.290
So what do you think, Cherokee?

523
00:28:45.290 --> 00:28:46.790
You think,
can we change it if we wanted to?

524
00:28:46.790 --> 00:28:47.840
What do you think?

525
00:28:47.840 --> 00:28:48.460
>> I don't know.
Yeah,

526
00:28:48.460 --> 00:28:51.820
there's gonna be a migration
process somewhere, right?

527
00:28:51.820 --> 00:28:55.140
>> No, all you have to do is
select backup the licensing.

528
00:28:55.140 --> 00:28:58.032
And notice it's not grayed out, so I can
change it even right here if I wanted to.

529
00:28:58.032 --> 00:29:01.165
So, if you choose to at one point,
change it, and

530
00:29:01.165 --> 00:29:02.489
the other-
>> I thought meant change

531
00:29:02.489 --> 00:29:03.189
the location for this instance.

532
00:29:03.189 --> 00:29:04.214
>> Nah,
I'm not worried about changing location.

533
00:29:04.214 --> 00:29:05.363
>> [LAUGH]
>> We can simply do that by

534
00:29:05.363 --> 00:29:05.872
adding in a new server.

535
00:29:05.872 --> 00:29:07.001
But overall though,

536
00:29:07.001 --> 00:29:10.649
notice that we can change even license
type if we want to if we want to.

537
00:29:10.649 --> 00:29:15.590
So it gives you that ability to do so
and so it's a great process.

538
00:29:15.590 --> 00:29:20.500
But once all that is set up,
you now have a single server deployment.

539
00:29:20.500 --> 00:29:22.540
I know, we did add in that second one.

540
00:29:22.540 --> 00:29:27.130
But we don't normally put everything on
the domain controller the way that we did.

541
00:29:27.130 --> 00:29:32.760
But at the same time, now everything is
registered and you are now ready to go and

542
00:29:32.760 --> 00:29:37.690
ready to do some real testing out in the
real world, and get everything configured

543
00:29:37.690 --> 00:29:41.660
and ready to use remote desktop
services with a single server.

544
00:29:41.660 --> 00:29:44.918
And that's kinda neat to actually
get all that setup and ready to go.

545
00:29:44.918 --> 00:29:47.010
>> Yeah, we're compliant now,
so good to go.

546
00:29:47.010 --> 00:29:49.970
Thank you so much for taking the time
to show us how to go ahead and

547
00:29:49.970 --> 00:29:52.800
set up our licensing server,
our licensing manager.

548
00:29:52.800 --> 00:29:55.940
And thank you, ladies and gentlemen for
turning in, but stay tuned,

549
00:29:55.940 --> 00:29:59.150
we do have more remote desktop
services headed your way.

550
00:29:59.150 --> 00:30:01.190
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for this show.

551
00:30:01.190 --> 00:30:02.500
Remember I'm Cherokee Boose.

552
00:30:02.500 --> 00:30:04.953
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

553
00:30:04.953 --> 00:30:13.187
[MUSIC]

554
00:30:13.187 --> 00:30:15.815
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Tune in to watch Cherokee and Ronnie discuss the role of a connection broker in a high availability environment.  Ronnie begins by creating a high availability cluster by adding and configuring the first machine of the cluster.
episodes.title: Deploy Connection Broker HA
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.324
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.324 --> 00:00:03.248
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.248 --> 00:00:08.308
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:08.308 --> 00:00:12.110
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.110 --> 00:00:15.020
>> Welcome to your
Remote Desktop Services show.

6
00:00:15.020 --> 00:00:17.160
I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.160 --> 00:00:20.900
In this episode,
we will be examining how to deploy

8
00:00:20.900 --> 00:00:23.680
a connection broker to
provide high availability.

9
00:00:23.680 --> 00:00:26.080
With us today, in studio,
we have Mr. Ronnie Wong.

10
00:00:26.080 --> 00:00:27.215
Thank you for joining us today, Ronnie.

11
00:00:27.215 --> 00:00:31.166
>> Well, thank you for having me back as
we continue on in our series right here

12
00:00:31.166 --> 00:00:33.490
for remote desktop services.

13
00:00:33.490 --> 00:00:36.500
When we first began, Cherokee, you and

14
00:00:36.500 --> 00:00:40.010
I started building just
a single server deployment.

15
00:00:40.010 --> 00:00:41.760
And that works in a pinch, right?

16
00:00:41.760 --> 00:00:45.650
If you don't have a lot of resources,
if you're a small company, we showed you,

17
00:00:45.650 --> 00:00:49.430
essentially, how to get everything
set up so it can work and provide for

18
00:00:49.430 --> 00:00:51.270
you what you need access to.

19
00:00:51.270 --> 00:00:53.735
Now, the problem with a single-server
deployment is simple,

20
00:00:53.735 --> 00:00:56.380
is that there is a single server.

21
00:00:56.380 --> 00:01:00.120
So what that normally means then is
if something happened to that server,

22
00:01:00.120 --> 00:01:02.300
it's not just one role that goes down,

23
00:01:02.300 --> 00:01:05.090
and you can simply replace it,
it's the entire server.

24
00:01:05.090 --> 00:01:08.940
So everything in your remote desktop
services may go down completely.

25
00:01:08.940 --> 00:01:12.420
And that brings everybody offline and
doesn't give us what we

26
00:01:12.420 --> 00:01:17.080
need a lot of times when we actually need
something, like remote desktop services.

27
00:01:17.080 --> 00:01:20.940
So instead, the way that we
normally try to deploy this,

28
00:01:20.940 --> 00:01:24.690
of course, is now gonna be using,
well, something else, right?

29
00:01:24.690 --> 00:01:28.258
The ability to spread out those
roles just a little bit more.

30
00:01:28.258 --> 00:01:32.106
The ability to have what we call
load balancing if we need to.

31
00:01:32.106 --> 00:01:33.411
The ability to have fault tolerance.

32
00:01:33.411 --> 00:01:36.640
So if one server fails,
the other one picks up again.

33
00:01:36.640 --> 00:01:41.113
So this is where we come into the realm
of what we call high availability, or

34
00:01:41.113 --> 00:01:43.110
the idea of clustering.

35
00:01:43.110 --> 00:01:49.550
Now, just when I say that term clustering,
the terminology has changed over time.

36
00:01:49.550 --> 00:01:54.330
So in previous iterations,
such as terminal servers, services back in

37
00:01:54.330 --> 00:01:59.310
Server 2008 and even earlier, the idea
of clustering was kind of the key.

38
00:01:59.310 --> 00:02:03.550
And even though I might have referred
to clustering before during the show,

39
00:02:03.550 --> 00:02:06.970
we're really talking about a concept that
now in Server 2012, they're saying, well,

40
00:02:06.970 --> 00:02:09.250
it's not really truly clustering anymore.

41
00:02:09.250 --> 00:02:12.779
We don't tend to use a network
load-balancer to help us to do a lot.

42
00:02:12.779 --> 00:02:17.367
But today, it really is just about
configuring for high availability.

43
00:02:17.367 --> 00:02:20.861
So they've tried to work it out to where
it's actually a little bit better for

44
00:02:20.861 --> 00:02:22.711
what we normally need the services for.

45
00:02:22.711 --> 00:02:24.082
And in that sense,

46
00:02:24.082 --> 00:02:30.330
let me kind of give you an instance of why
this is a better solution than before.

47
00:02:30.330 --> 00:02:34.904
So in previous iterations of terminal
services, or the idea of remote desktop

48
00:02:34.904 --> 00:02:39.940
services, we always had what we called
an active/passive type of cluster.

49
00:02:39.940 --> 00:02:42.690
And this essentially meant that
everybody really just connected to

50
00:02:42.690 --> 00:02:46.810
one of those servers, and the other one
would kind of stay in the background.

51
00:02:46.810 --> 00:02:49.750
And then if something else happened,
then the other server would kick in and

52
00:02:49.750 --> 00:02:51.060
take over.

53
00:02:51.060 --> 00:02:52.600
And even though that provided for

54
00:02:52.600 --> 00:02:56.570
us a little bit of what we needed,
which was the idea of failover,

55
00:02:56.570 --> 00:03:01.480
it really didn’t help to do the idea
of scalability of what we really need.

56
00:03:01.480 --> 00:03:03.750
Which is, of course,
the ability to handle more and

57
00:03:03.750 --> 00:03:07.140
more loads as my company
continues to grow.

58
00:03:07.140 --> 00:03:12.900
So instead, now in Server 2012 with RDS,

59
00:03:12.900 --> 00:03:16.430
we can actually implement what they
call an active/active cluster,

60
00:03:16.430 --> 00:03:21.750
per se, in which both servers
can actually handle the load.

61
00:03:21.750 --> 00:03:25.470
So when we start talking about the idea
of high availability in this sense,

62
00:03:25.470 --> 00:03:30.090
we're ensuring for failover and
for scalability at the same time.

63
00:03:30.090 --> 00:03:34.470
And that is what we really want to
implement and get set up and started.

64
00:03:34.470 --> 00:03:39.100
Now, there were a couple ways that I could
have started to bring this show to you,

65
00:03:39.100 --> 00:03:41.450
which was to try and

66
00:03:41.450 --> 00:03:47.170
reconfigure what we had already set up so
that we don't have a lot of work to do.

67
00:03:47.170 --> 00:03:49.190
But normally, when you begin and

68
00:03:49.190 --> 00:03:52.480
you start working with a customer,
that's where you start off.

69
00:03:52.480 --> 00:03:56.630
So in the first scenario, essentially,
we kind of said here it is, we're a small

70
00:03:56.630 --> 00:04:01.740
company, and we just need to get this
done and started and see what happens.

71
00:04:01.740 --> 00:04:04.290
But now, as we go on to,
let's say, to another customer and

72
00:04:04.290 --> 00:04:07.860
they're saying we need this idea,
we need the idea of load balancing.

73
00:04:07.860 --> 00:04:12.660
We need this idea of being able to have
failover provided and the scaling that we

74
00:04:12.660 --> 00:04:16.850
need because we know that our company is
gonna be growing in the next year or so.

75
00:04:16.850 --> 00:04:21.748
Well, on that single-server deployment
that we did earlier when we built that

76
00:04:21.748 --> 00:04:25.740
single server,
it really can only be limited so much so.

77
00:04:25.740 --> 00:04:29.870
We can try and add in a second server and
kind of get it in, but

78
00:04:29.870 --> 00:04:33.870
if we didn't start off with the planning
of it, it makes it much more difficult.

79
00:04:33.870 --> 00:04:36.400
So what we're gonna do is we're gonna
start at the beginning this time,

80
00:04:36.400 --> 00:04:39.840
and we're gonna choose some different
options that gives us more granularity

81
00:04:39.840 --> 00:04:40.940
than what we need.

82
00:04:40.940 --> 00:04:45.200
So my lab has changed a little bit where
I've added in a second RDS server,

83
00:04:45.200 --> 00:04:46.330
is what I've done.

84
00:04:46.330 --> 00:04:48.860
So now, instead of actually
working with one server,

85
00:04:48.860 --> 00:04:51.226
we're gonna be working
with two servers instead.

86
00:04:51.226 --> 00:04:55.534
And we're gonna start that deployment
over, and then we'll start configuring for

87
00:04:55.534 --> 00:04:59.260
the high availability,
especially on this connection-broker idea.

88
00:04:59.260 --> 00:05:03.770
And this is the key
component inside of RDS for

89
00:05:03.770 --> 00:05:07.910
us and Windows Server 2012 is that we
need to start off clustering with that

90
00:05:07.910 --> 00:05:10.430
because that's what decides
where things go, right?

91
00:05:10.430 --> 00:05:13.899
The connection broker's what decides where
the client's gonna get shuffled off to,

92
00:05:13.899 --> 00:05:15.666
and that's why we wanna start right there.

93
00:05:15.666 --> 00:05:17.186
And that's the way we're gonna do.

94
00:05:17.186 --> 00:05:19.799
And then later on we'll bring in,
actually,

95
00:05:19.799 --> 00:05:22.890
being able to load balance
between the session hosts.

96
00:05:22.890 --> 00:05:25.170
But for right now,
let's just start off with that.

97
00:05:25.170 --> 00:05:26.410
>> All right.
>> So here it is.

98
00:05:26.410 --> 00:05:30.780
Let's go back to my screen, and we'll
begin with the deployment idea, okay?

99
00:05:30.780 --> 00:05:37.180
So here on my screen, I am actually on my
domain controller right here, on DC01.

100
00:05:37.180 --> 00:05:40.270
And we're simply gonna start adding in
everything that we learned about in

101
00:05:40.270 --> 00:05:41.690
the previous episodes, but

102
00:05:41.690 --> 00:05:45.570
we're gonna choose a couple of different
options as we go through here, okay?

103
00:05:45.570 --> 00:05:48.080
So the first thing that I wanna do
here now that everything is up,

104
00:05:48.080 --> 00:05:51.118
I need to make sure that the machine
that I have of course are domain joined,

105
00:05:51.118 --> 00:05:55.810
they're installed with Windows Server
2012, and everything is ready to go.

106
00:05:55.810 --> 00:05:59.230
But we're gonna see that we're gonna have
to add in a little bit more if we want to

107
00:05:59.230 --> 00:06:01.580
do this idea of clustering here.

108
00:06:01.580 --> 00:06:05.300
One, of course, is that we're gonna take
a look here, after we get some things

109
00:06:05.300 --> 00:06:10.990
installed, started here, is that we're
gonna need to install a SQL Server.

110
00:06:10.990 --> 00:06:13.375
Now the great thing is if you
already have a SQL Server running,

111
00:06:13.375 --> 00:06:14.681
you don't have to worry about it.

112
00:06:14.681 --> 00:06:16.913
All you have to do is kind of
change a few configurations,

113
00:06:16.913 --> 00:06:19.730
and we'll show you what
configurations you have to change.

114
00:06:19.730 --> 00:06:23.201
But if you don't, you have to install
that, and you'll have to get it up and

115
00:06:23.201 --> 00:06:25.767
running and make sure that
that connection can be seen.

116
00:06:25.767 --> 00:06:29.240
And you'll have to deal with a little
bit of active directory groups too.

117
00:06:29.240 --> 00:06:31.785
>> So, Ronnie,
we didn't install a SQL Server previously.

118
00:06:31.785 --> 00:06:33.860
Is that something we're gonna
be looking at in a few minutes?

119
00:06:33.860 --> 00:06:34.418
>> We are.

120
00:06:34.418 --> 00:06:36.070
>> Cool.
>> We're gonna actually end up taking

121
00:06:36.070 --> 00:06:39.490
a look at that, but I'm not gonna do
a full-blown SQL Server installation.

122
00:06:39.490 --> 00:06:42.543
For our proof of concept,
I'm just gonna use SQL Express.

123
00:06:42.543 --> 00:06:45.095
And even though I'm gonna
say it should be quicker,

124
00:06:45.095 --> 00:06:48.404
there's no guarantee in
the installation process it's quicker.

125
00:06:48.404 --> 00:06:51.964
Now, this does change the hardware
configuration a little bit.

126
00:06:51.964 --> 00:06:54.420
I'm gonna install it onto
this domain controller, but

127
00:06:54.420 --> 00:06:57.130
we're gonna do it after
a couple of processes here.

128
00:06:57.130 --> 00:07:01.630
But it does require usually at least
four gigs of RAM on your SQL Server.

129
00:07:01.630 --> 00:07:04.370
So make sure you put it on
a machine with four gigs RAM, or

130
00:07:04.370 --> 00:07:06.830
check out whatever
the minimum requirements are.

131
00:07:06.830 --> 00:07:08.550
If you already have a SQL Server up and
running,

132
00:07:08.550 --> 00:07:12.860
just make sure you can connect to that
SQL Server, and that is gonna be the key.

133
00:07:12.860 --> 00:07:14.860
Then we'll actually see some other
elements that we have to add

134
00:07:14.860 --> 00:07:17.280
into the remote desktop services

135
00:07:17.280 --> 00:07:21.090
servers to be able to connect
back to that SQL Server as well.

136
00:07:21.090 --> 00:07:23.990
Because in clustering,
we need that database.

137
00:07:23.990 --> 00:07:28.900
Even though there's a Windows Internal
Database that can be used with

138
00:07:28.900 --> 00:07:35.040
a single-server deployment scenario, once
you start now having multiple machines

139
00:07:35.040 --> 00:07:38.750
doing this, now you're gonna actually
need something a little bit more robust.

140
00:07:38.750 --> 00:07:43.270
So I'm just gonna use a SQL Server
Express, like I said, to kind of really at

141
00:07:43.270 --> 00:07:47.240
least show you the implementation
of it at the beginning here.

142
00:07:47.240 --> 00:07:51.274
So let's go ahead and start by installing,
well, the role that we need.

143
00:07:51.274 --> 00:07:53.952
So once I'm actually
on the server manager,

144
00:07:53.952 --> 00:07:57.972
I'm on the dashboard,
I'm gonna click on Add roles and features.

145
00:07:57.972 --> 00:07:59.316
And before I do that.

146
00:07:59.316 --> 00:08:03.165
I realize I forgot something right away
Cherokee which is I can't manage those

147
00:08:03.165 --> 00:08:06.162
servers if they're not actually
part of my server manager.

148
00:08:06.162 --> 00:08:08.370
>> That's right.
>> So, let me go ahead and make sure.

149
00:08:08.370 --> 00:08:09.960
So, all servers and

150
00:08:09.960 --> 00:08:14.280
now you can actually see where I've
added in already those picker servers.

151
00:08:14.280 --> 00:08:20.220
I tried to keep my lab environment fairly
simple notice I sequenced my IP addresses.

152
00:08:20.220 --> 00:08:21.740
And that's just easy for me to remember.

153
00:08:21.740 --> 00:08:25.820
Now, if you don't wanna do that you can
