604
00:32:24.920 --> 00:32:26.520
Inside of Active Directory Users and

605
00:32:26.520 --> 00:32:30.360
Computers I made a group
called RDS Connection Brokers.

606
00:32:30.360 --> 00:32:31.700
Why?
Because it was simple and

607
00:32:31.700 --> 00:32:33.560
I could remember, okay.

608
00:32:33.560 --> 00:32:36.880
The other thing that I did
is I added in both RD01 and

609
00:32:36.880 --> 00:32:40.630
RD02 into that Connection Brokers group.

610
00:32:40.630 --> 00:32:44.120
Cuz I know that both of them are gonna
need to access this SQL Server

611
00:32:44.120 --> 00:32:45.650
when they connect.

612
00:32:45.650 --> 00:32:47.043
So I'm gonna click on the Search.

613
00:32:49.357 --> 00:32:52.520
And then, here's where it gets tricky.

614
00:32:52.520 --> 00:32:55.500
Notice it says User or
built-in security principals.

615
00:32:55.500 --> 00:33:00.340
Well, this is something that I created,
so it's not actually for users here.

616
00:33:00.340 --> 00:33:04.954
I'm gonna click that and then select
Groups because I created that RDS group.

617
00:33:04.954 --> 00:33:13.311
Now I can type in RDS Connection Brokers,
Here and

618
00:33:13.311 --> 00:33:17.270
then select Check Names, verify that
it underlines which means it found it.

619
00:33:19.400 --> 00:33:22.653
And now,
we've added in the Connection Brokers

620
00:33:22.653 --> 00:33:25.675
group being able to log
into that SQL server.

621
00:33:25.675 --> 00:33:29.006
Well, what I needed to do when
I log into the SQL server?

622
00:33:29.006 --> 00:33:34.325
This is where I need to select the Server
Roles and the first thing it has is,

623
00:33:34.325 --> 00:33:40.400
hey I can access it pubicly that's fine,
but I need the DBCreator role as well.

624
00:33:40.400 --> 00:33:41.810
Make sure you mark that.

625
00:33:41.810 --> 00:33:45.320
You don't do that, you can have that SQL
Server connection broker running all day

626
00:33:45.320 --> 00:33:48.350
long, it's not gonna matter, okay.

627
00:33:48.350 --> 00:33:51.570
So that is something else
that needs to be done there.

628
00:33:51.570 --> 00:33:54.540
Now there are a couple of other
things that we'll run into.

629
00:33:54.540 --> 00:33:58.010
Especially if you don't get it set up but
we'll take care of that

630
00:33:58.010 --> 00:34:01.660
when we set up the second connection
broker to get connected in.

631
00:34:01.660 --> 00:34:04.290
We'll have to come back in here to
Mappings and we'll have to change

632
00:34:04.290 --> 00:34:07.382
a couple of items too, but we'll worry
about that a little bit later on.

633
00:34:08.545 --> 00:34:10.985
>> Yeah Ronnie you said there were several
different things that we needed to

634
00:34:10.985 --> 00:34:11.555
complete.

635
00:34:11.555 --> 00:34:14.605
So it looks like we're about out
of time for this particular show.

636
00:34:14.605 --> 00:34:16.215
How about we just go ahead and

637
00:34:16.215 --> 00:34:21.075
pick back up with a part two to continue
our configuration for our broker here?

638
00:34:21.075 --> 00:34:25.930
>> That should actually be it for
at least the SQL Server side, right.

639
00:34:25.930 --> 00:34:29.210
We still have to configure the other two
to make sure that everything is actually

640
00:34:29.210 --> 00:34:30.060
ready and going and

641
00:34:30.060 --> 00:34:32.520
of course the high availability,
which we haven't gotten to yet.

642
00:34:32.520 --> 00:34:34.040
So this is a great place to stop.

643
00:34:34.040 --> 00:34:34.860
>> Okay, great.

644
00:34:34.860 --> 00:34:37.720
So thank you so much for joining us today
and thank you ladies and gentleman for

645
00:34:37.720 --> 00:34:39.650
being here as well, but
we're gonna go ahead and

646
00:34:39.650 --> 00:34:41.540
sign off for this particular show.

647
00:34:41.540 --> 00:34:42.920
Remember, I'm Cherokee Boose.

648
00:34:42.920 --> 00:34:43.640
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

649
00:34:43.640 --> 00:34:47.350
>> See you next time here at IT Pro TV.

650
00:34:47.350 --> 00:34:53.393
[MUSIC]

651
00:34:53.393 --> 00:34:56.561
>> Thank you for watching ITProTv.

episodes.description: This episode is a continuation where Ronnie and Cherokee walk thru the detailed process of configuring the connection broker cluster for high availability. Ronnie will also perform an installation SQL express 2012.
episodes.title: Deploy Connection Broker HA Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:01.190
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.190 --> 00:00:02.428
I'm your host Don Pizet.

3
00:00:02.428 --> 00:00:06.460
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.460 --> 00:00:08.260
>> [MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.260 --> 00:00:11.418
You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.418 --> 00:00:14.670
>> Welcome to your
Remote Desktop Services show.

7
00:00:14.670 --> 00:00:16.520
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:16.520 --> 00:00:19.220
If you've been following along,
you'll know this is actually a part two.

9
00:00:19.220 --> 00:00:23.590
In the previous episode, Ronnie had just
finished up installing that SQL Server

10
00:00:23.590 --> 00:00:25.990
on our broker for a high availability.

11
00:00:25.990 --> 00:00:27.610
We're gonna go ahead and continue.

12
00:00:27.610 --> 00:00:29.410
Thank you so much for
joining us today, Ronnie.

13
00:00:29.410 --> 00:00:32.620
>> Well, thank you for having me
back as we continue on the rest of

14
00:00:32.620 --> 00:00:35.220
the installation here for
a high availability.

15
00:00:35.220 --> 00:00:38.430
And you're right, we'd just finished
the installation of SQL Server.

16
00:00:38.430 --> 00:00:42.330
We showed you where you could go in and
where you have to go in and configure it

17
00:00:42.330 --> 00:00:47.258
so that now our remote desktop
connection brokers, right, can connect

18
00:00:47.258 --> 00:00:51.820
into that SQL Server and, of course, be
able to create databases as they need to.

19
00:00:51.820 --> 00:00:55.550
Now, there's still a problem that we have
to worry about and deal with, and that,

20
00:00:55.550 --> 00:00:58.050
of course,
is the Windows Firewall, itself.

21
00:00:59.110 --> 00:01:02.850
Even though it allows for
connections be open and for

22
00:01:02.850 --> 00:01:07.410
us to do this, but it really doesn't allow
for connections to come in too easily.

23
00:01:07.410 --> 00:01:10.620
So that SQL Server right now
is essentially protected.

24
00:01:10.620 --> 00:01:14.210
Even if we set up everything else that
we need to, that means we still need to

25
00:01:14.210 --> 00:01:16.630
actually open up something in
the firewall to help us out.

26
00:01:16.630 --> 00:01:18.210
So let's go ahead and configure that, and

27
00:01:18.210 --> 00:01:22.090
then we'll move on through the next
part of the configuration that we need.

28
00:01:22.090 --> 00:01:24.460
So the great thing is it's
relatively simple to do so.

29
00:01:24.460 --> 00:01:26.770
Let's go ahead and take a look here.

30
00:01:26.770 --> 00:01:27.720
On my machine,

31
00:01:27.720 --> 00:01:32.210
I'm gonna click on the Start button in
the lower left-hand corner of the screen.

32
00:01:34.380 --> 00:01:38.190
And once we do that,
we are going to type in,

33
00:01:38.190 --> 00:01:40.370
I'm just gonna start typing here,
firewall.

34
00:01:42.280 --> 00:01:46.350
Select the Windows Firewall with
Advanced Security is what I'm going to do.

35
00:01:46.350 --> 00:01:48.070
>> Now, Ronnie,
is there a particular port or

36
00:01:48.070 --> 00:01:49.650
what type of rule would be setting here?

37
00:01:49.650 --> 00:01:51.960
>> Well,
we have two options at this point.

38
00:01:51.960 --> 00:01:54.388
So it really depends on your-
>> Prerogative?

39
00:01:54.388 --> 00:01:54.961
>> Preference.

40
00:01:54.961 --> 00:01:57.850
Yeah, it really does,
It just depends on what you like to do.

41
00:01:57.850 --> 00:02:01.640
One, we could have just used the Windows
Firewall and made an exception for

42
00:02:01.640 --> 00:02:03.315
SQL Server, if we chose to.

43
00:02:03.315 --> 00:02:03.850
>> Okay.
So just

44
00:02:03.850 --> 00:02:06.330
allow that entire thing to come through.

45
00:02:06.330 --> 00:02:10.570
I don't like that, but
people will do it, and

46
00:02:10.570 --> 00:02:13.300
that's perfectly fine and you can do that.

47
00:02:13.300 --> 00:02:15.630
I like doing this where I'm going
to set an exception just for

48
00:02:15.630 --> 00:02:18.550
the port that we need, which is port 1433.

49
00:02:18.550 --> 00:02:21.060
That's the default for
SQL Server, instead.

50
00:02:21.060 --> 00:02:25.020
Now, I like opening up just one
port because if you go and say,

51
00:02:25.020 --> 00:02:30.410
look, here it is, the entire SQL Server
can, of course, get access through.

52
00:02:30.410 --> 00:02:32.790
And it does it for TCP as well as UDP.

53
00:02:32.790 --> 00:02:34.856
It gives you every access in.

54
00:02:34.856 --> 00:02:39.010
It's saying SQL Server's open,
so anytime somebody can

55
00:02:39.010 --> 00:02:42.690
figure out a vulnerability to exploit,
well, that means they'll be able to do so.

56
00:02:42.690 --> 00:02:45.240
I like opening up only
the specific ports I need to.

57
00:02:45.240 --> 00:02:46.710
It doesn't mean that you
have to do it that way.

58
00:02:46.710 --> 00:02:48.290
It doesn't mean that I'm right.

59
00:02:48.290 --> 00:02:50.130
You may go, there's no harm in that.

60
00:02:50.130 --> 00:02:51.422
Perfectly fine.

61
00:02:51.422 --> 00:02:53.396
I have my particular preference,

62
00:02:53.396 --> 00:02:56.808
which is only open up the minuscule
amount that you need to.

63
00:02:56.808 --> 00:02:58.130
And that's what we're going to do.

64
00:02:58.130 --> 00:03:02.680
I'm gonna select an inbound rule and
then click on New Rule.

65
00:03:02.680 --> 00:03:06.050
When I do so,
I'm gonna select the port number for

66
00:03:06.050 --> 00:03:10.600
what we need, click Next and
then just do it for TCP here.

67
00:03:10.600 --> 00:03:11.770
This is port 14.

68
00:03:11.770 --> 00:03:13.160
>> 33?
33.

69
00:03:13.160 --> 00:03:14.789
Click Next.

70
00:03:14.789 --> 00:03:17.870
We're gonna allow for
that connection to happen.

71
00:03:19.260 --> 00:03:21.350
Click Next, I'm gonna do it for
all the connections.

72
00:03:21.350 --> 00:03:26.130
We're not gonna be connecting
in too much on public too often.

73
00:03:26.130 --> 00:03:29.920
But I'll just call this one SQL Server,
nice and easy for us to do.

74
00:03:31.110 --> 00:03:34.450
Click Finish, and
now the connection's in for

75
00:03:34.450 --> 00:03:37.549
those remote desktop connection brokers.

76
00:03:37.549 --> 00:03:41.162
Once we install the client, they should
be able to connect and reach over and

77
00:03:41.162 --> 00:03:42.300
do what they need to do.

78
00:03:42.300 --> 00:03:46.130
All right, so
that kind of another piece in the puzzle.

79
00:03:46.130 --> 00:03:49.010
The installation of the SQL Server,
itself, making sure,

80
00:03:49.010 --> 00:03:51.870
of course,
the roles are installed that we need to.

81
00:03:51.870 --> 00:03:53.510
Doing simple things like this, right.

82
00:03:53.510 --> 00:03:58.110
Any of these can be failing in your
component when trying to set everything up

83
00:03:58.110 --> 00:03:59.580
the way that we want.

84
00:03:59.580 --> 00:04:03.810
Now, other things also have
to kind of occur as well.

85
00:04:03.810 --> 00:04:07.820
When we set up the single server
deployment, right, we created

86
00:04:07.820 --> 00:04:12.130
a certificate for rd1 because that was
the only server we were going to use.

87
00:04:12.130 --> 00:04:14.691
So I simply used the name of that server.

88
00:04:14.691 --> 00:04:18.138
But now that we're setting up for
high availability, in other words,

89
00:04:18.138 --> 00:04:21.240
I know I'm going to be using more
than one server to connect in and

90
00:04:21.240 --> 00:04:22.685
do everything that I need to.

91
00:04:22.685 --> 00:04:25.930
Well, which one do I want
people connecting to?

92
00:04:25.930 --> 00:04:30.812
If I get just a certificate for rd1, well,
that's always gonna send everybody where?

93
00:04:30.812 --> 00:04:31.632
To rd1.

94
00:04:31.632 --> 00:04:37.270
If I get one just for rd2, that's always
gonna send and collect there for rd2.

95
00:04:37.270 --> 00:04:40.430
So we need to, of course,
then change that up.

96
00:04:40.430 --> 00:04:45.000
But before we do that, we also want
to create, of course, a DNS entry.

97
00:04:45.000 --> 00:04:50.230
And this is a specific type of DNS entry
that we call a round robin DNS entry,

98
00:04:50.230 --> 00:04:51.410
instead.

99
00:04:51.410 --> 00:04:53.920
So that is the next thing
we are going to set up.

100
00:04:55.270 --> 00:04:58.934
On my server manager, over on
the left-hand side, I'm gonna choose DNS.

101
00:04:58.934 --> 00:05:05.240
I'm gonna right-click on the DC01 and
select My DNS Manager.

102
00:05:06.600 --> 00:05:10.177
And it's inside of the DNS manager
that I need to configure this.

103
00:05:10.177 --> 00:05:10.690
>> All right,

104
00:05:10.690 --> 00:05:13.882
Ronnie, so just to clarify that term
that you said about round robining.

105
00:05:13.882 --> 00:05:15.750
>> Hm-hm.
>> So what we're doing is we're gonna be

106
00:05:15.750 --> 00:05:19.152
having two different machines, and they're
pointing to one particular name here.

107
00:05:19.152 --> 00:05:23.133
So it looks like from the outside we're
just connecting to one machine when,

108
00:05:23.133 --> 00:05:26.730
in fact, we actually have two physical,
or virtual, machines.

109
00:05:26.730 --> 00:05:29.840
>> Correct, and
that's what the whole goal is, right.

110
00:05:29.840 --> 00:05:34.272
For high availability we don't really care
that somebody wants to connect rd01 or

111
00:05:34.272 --> 00:05:35.030
rd02.

112
00:05:35.030 --> 00:05:35.887
We just want them to connect.

113
00:05:35.887 --> 00:05:40.000
So we're gonna set up another name and
areas, if you want to, to do this.

114
00:05:40.000 --> 00:05:44.063
Now, the that we do this is that we
don't actually set up just records,

115
00:05:44.063 --> 00:05:45.847
we just set up a brand new zone.

116
00:05:45.847 --> 00:05:49.567
I'm gonna right-click,
select New Zone, click Next.

117
00:05:49.567 --> 00:05:53.400
It's gonna be a primary zone,
that's perfectly fine.

118
00:05:53.400 --> 00:05:57.615
I want it on all my DNS servers right now,
it's only one, so no real big deal there.

119
00:05:57.615 --> 00:06:02.930
It's here, that I want to set up
how I want people to connect in.

120
00:06:02.930 --> 00:06:06.637
So I'm simply gonna just call
it rds to make it easy for me,

121
00:06:06.637 --> 00:06:09.110
more then everybody else here.

122
00:06:09.110 --> 00:06:10.169
Just call it rds.

123
00:06:11.505 --> 00:06:13.110
Okay, now you can call
it whatever you want to.

124
00:06:13.110 --> 00:06:14.460
You can call it Gateway,

125
00:06:14.460 --> 00:06:18.530
you can call it whatever that you
want people to connect in as.

126
00:06:18.530 --> 00:06:21.972
But I'm just gonna use rds, click Next.

127
00:06:21.972 --> 00:06:26.000
And now we're gonna allow for
updates, perfectly fine.

128
00:06:26.000 --> 00:06:27.429
Click Finish.

129
00:06:27.429 --> 00:06:31.651
This is where we have to create
a couple of records, right.

130
00:06:31.651 --> 00:06:36.036
I'm gonna expand out that new
zone by going inside of it and

131
00:06:36.036 --> 00:06:37.950
creating a new A record.

132
00:06:37.950 --> 00:06:40.370
Now, if I create a new A record and
I add in a name here,

133
00:06:40.370 --> 00:06:42.940
I want you to notice this second line.

134
00:06:42.940 --> 00:06:45.992
So let's say I go, I need one for rd01.

135
00:06:45.992 --> 00:06:50.198
Well, I really don't want
it connecting to rd01, so

136
00:06:50.198 --> 00:06:53.696
instead I'm just gonna
leave that one blank.

137
00:06:53.696 --> 00:06:55.689
Well, let me see if I can get out of that.

138
00:06:55.689 --> 00:06:56.532
There we go.

139
00:06:56.532 --> 00:07:02.138
And then 10.0.46 201.

140
00:07:02.138 --> 00:07:06.556
Now, notice the fully
qualified domain name part.

141
00:07:06.556 --> 00:07:08.410
Still available, and I can click Add Host.

142
00:07:11.417 --> 00:07:16.530
And there we go, I have now
created a new host for that zone.

143
00:07:16.530 --> 00:07:20.910
And do the same thing here for,
well, my other one,

144
00:07:20.910 --> 00:07:27.010
which is gonna be 10.0.46.202,
if I remember the IP addresses okay.

145
00:07:27.010 --> 00:07:28.520
>> That is correct.

146
00:07:28.520 --> 00:07:31.560
Click Add Host, and click OK.

147
00:07:31.560 --> 00:07:34.370
So both of those should be able to respond

148
00:07:34.370 --> 00:07:38.762
to anybody that's connecting
in by rds.ITProTVDemo.com.

149
00:07:38.762 --> 00:07:39.582
>> Okay.
>> Okay,

150
00:07:39.582 --> 00:07:43.920
so that's the zones that are actually
set up for us to be able to do this.

151
00:07:45.310 --> 00:07:48.846
Now, once we've got that,
we've pretty much got just about

152
00:07:48.846 --> 00:07:52.654
everything that we need, except for
just a couple of options now.

153
00:07:52.654 --> 00:07:57.091
Now, one of the other things that I've
been talking about is that there is a SQL

154
00:07:57.091 --> 00:07:59.459
client connection that needs to be done.

155
00:07:59.459 --> 00:08:05.153
So, I need to go over to the RD01 and
let's add that client connection in now.

156
00:08:07.797 --> 00:08:10.436
Remember to log on as the administrator.

157
00:08:16.325 --> 00:08:21.605
And once I do so,
we're going to run just a simple MSI file.

158
00:08:21.605 --> 00:08:25.701
Now, we'll add in the single client and
we won't even worry about it again.

159
00:08:25.701 --> 00:08:28.796
We won't have to configure it or anything
else, but it does need to be run now.

160
00:08:31.184 --> 00:08:35.193
So inside of my shared folder,
I need to look and

161
00:08:35.193 --> 00:08:39.003
it is the kind of
the miniscule one that says,

162
00:08:39.003 --> 00:08:43.040
sqln native client is
what we're looking for.

163
00:08:43.040 --> 00:08:43.607
>> All right.

164
00:08:43.607 --> 00:08:47.500
>> That's why it does that and you can
download this right from Microsoft.

165
00:08:47.500 --> 00:08:48.796
Select install and

166
00:08:48.796 --> 00:08:53.339
we'll see it will kind of run
an installation file here for us too.

167
00:08:57.663 --> 00:08:59.968
Select Run.

168
00:08:59.968 --> 00:09:03.853
Now if it's missing any prerequisites,
it'll show up during the install.

169
00:09:03.853 --> 00:09:05.239
That's what we'll end up seeing.

170
00:09:05.239 --> 00:09:06.898
You can also see there's
that note first thing, hey,

171
00:09:06.898 --> 00:09:09.149
Ronnie, you haven't licensed anything yet,
cuz we haven't set it up.

172
00:09:10.900 --> 00:09:11.520
Click Next.

173
00:09:13.900 --> 00:09:14.770
Accept the terms.

174
00:09:16.110 --> 00:09:20.185
We don't need the actual SDK for
the software development kit,

175
00:09:20.185 --> 00:09:22.533
we just need the client components.

176
00:09:22.533 --> 00:09:24.766
Click Install and let it do its thing.

177
00:09:27.252 --> 00:09:31.047
Now just because I'm trying
to save a little bit of time,

178
00:09:31.047 --> 00:09:36.106
I'm gonna come over here to the second
one even though I haven't set it up yet

179
00:09:36.106 --> 00:09:40.137
and I'm simply gonna add this role in or
that client in here,

180
00:09:40.137 --> 00:09:43.962
